description: It was built 1852 as a Chapel, Ebenezer Chapel and the adjoining cottage was the manse. the corner stone was laid on 6/8/1852. The trustees of the Pride of Clapham, Oddfellows purchased the chapel in 1908 and are still the current owners.

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: The building was constructed in 1852. The name and year of build is shown in a pediment over the main door. It was constructed for the Ebenezer Strict Baptists. The corner stone was laid on 6th August 1852 and was opened in January 1853. The chapel was named Ebenezer Chapel, and the cottage attached was the manse, as Ebenezer Cottage. With in a few years the Baptists moved to a new location to Fitzwillliam Road.

factsheet.heading: The Building Today
paragraphs: In 1908 the chapel was purchased by the Trustees of the Loyal Pride of Clapham Lodge, South London District of the Independent Order of Oddfellows Manchester Unity Friendly Society. The Manchester Unity of Oddfellows formed in 1810 and is one of the oldest and longest established friendly societies. They are a non profit organisation owned by their members.

The Society still hold their meetings and social events there. Some of the building is rented out to a Buddhist group and the Ebenezer Cottage is rented out to private tenants.
 
Inside the building are boards that show names of Past Grand Masters and Presidents and even shows members who served in both world wars. In tribute to the brothers, there was some damage that was caused from a World War II bomb, this was never repaired.

factsheet.heading: Green Plaque
paragraphs: A Green Plaque awarded to the building was unveiled by Edmund Bird, Heritage Advisor to the Mayor of London and former Lambeth Conservation Officer on the 16th April 2015. This was thanks to the Clapham Society.

name: Ebenezer Cottage
